generic: Factor IX Fc Fusion Protein Recombinant
drugs: Factor IX Fc Fusion Protein Recombinant

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Factor IX Fc Fusion Protein Recombinant

sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• dose = body weight (kg) times desired factor IX increase (international units/dL or % of normal) times 1 (international unit/kg per international units/dL)
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: minor surgery (50% to 80% of normal factor IX level required) single IV bolus infusion, repeat as needed after 24 to 48 hours until bleeding ceases and healing occurs
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: major surgery (60% to 100% of normal factor IX initial level required) IV bolus infusion; consider repeat dose after 6 to 10 hours then every 24 hours for first 3 days; after day 3 may decrease dose and increase interval to every 48 hours or longer until bleeding ceases and healing occurs
  • Bleeding, To prevent or reduce frequency of bleeding episodes; Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: 50 international units/kg IV bolus infusion once weekly OR 100 international units/kg once IV bolus infusion every 10 days; adjust dose based on patient response
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: minor to moderate bleeding (30% to 60% of normal Factor IX level required) IV bolus infusion; repeat every 48 hours with further evidence of bleeding
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: major bleeding (80% to 100% of normal Factor IX level required) IV bolus infusion; consider repeat dose after 6 to 10 hours then every 24 hours for the first 3 days; after day 3 may decrease dose and increase interval to every 48 hours or longer until bleeding ceases and healing occurs

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• (12 years or older) dose = body weight (kg) times desired factor IX increase (international units/dL or % of normal) times 1 (international unit/kg per international units/dL)
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: minor surgery (50% to 80% of normal factor IX level required) single IV bolus infusion, repeat as needed after 24 to 48 hours until bleeding ceases and healing occurs
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: major surgery (60% to 100% of normal factor IX initial level required) IV bolus infusion; consider repeat dose after 6 to 10 hours then every 24 hours for first 3 days; after day 3 may decrease dose and increase interval to every 48 hours or longer until bleeding ceases and healing occurs
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: (younger than 12 years) dose increase or more frequent administration may be required
  • Bleeding, To prevent or reduce frequency of bleeding episodes; Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: (12 years or older) 50 international units/kg IV bolus infusion once weekly OR 100 international units/kg once IV bolus every 10 days; adjust dose based on patient response
  • Bleeding, To prevent or reduce frequency of bleeding episodes; Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: (younger than 12 years) dose increase or more frequent administration may be required
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: minor to moderate bleeding (30% to 60% of normal Factor IX level required) IV bolus infusion; repeat every 48 hours with further evidence of bleeding
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: major bleeding (80% to 100% of normal Factor IX level required) IV bolus infusion; consider repeat dose after 6 to 10 hours then every 24 hours for the first 3 days; after day 3 may decrease dose and increase interval to every 48 hours or longer until bleeding ceases and healing occurs
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B: (younger than 12 years) dose increase or more frequent administration may be required

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• children younger than 12 years: increased dose or more frequent administration may be needed
  • children 12 years or older: dose adjustment not usually necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bleeding, Perioperative; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B
  • Bleeding, To prevent or reduce frequency of bleeding episodes; Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B
  • Bleeding; Treatment and Prophylaxis - Hemophilia B

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to Factor IX or any of its excipients

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, have been reported; increased risk with the presence of neutralizing antibodies to Factor IX; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if hypersensitivity occurs
  • neutralizing antibody formation has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • thromboembolic complications may occur; increased risk with continuous infusion through central venous catheter; administer as a bolus infusion over several minutes
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Oral paresthesia (1.7%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (1.7%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Thromboembolic disorder
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Antibody development, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Renal:Urinary tract obstruction (0.8%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Factor IX Fc fusion protein recombinant transiently replaces missing coagulation factor IX required to achieve hemostasis during bleeding episodes in patients with hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency). The Fc region of the drug binds to the neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn). FcRn aids in delay of lysosomal degradation of immunoglobulins by cycling them back into circulation and increasing their plasma t(1/2). Hemophilia B patients have a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), which is an established test for the biological activity of factor IX; factor IX Fc fusion protein recombinant therapy shortens the aPTT over the effective dosing period.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Vss: 327 mL/kg
  • Vss, pediatrics: 349 mL/kg (2 to 5 years); 303 mL/kg (6 to 11 years); 326 mL/kg (12 to 17 years)

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Total body clearance: 3.304 mL/kg/hr (50 international units/kg); 2.65 mL/kg/hr (100 international units/kg)
  • Total body clearance, pediatrics: 4.406 mL/hr/kg (2 to 5 years); 3.613 mL/hr/kg (6 to 11 years); 3.483 mL/hr/kg (12 to 17 years)

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 86.52 hours
  • Pediatrics: 66.4 hours (2 to 5 years); 72.23 hours (6 to 11 years); 83.59 hours (12 to 17 years)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • allow vial and prefilled diluent syringe to reach room temperature before use
  • slowly add diluent provided into drug vial; swirl gently until completely dissolved; do not shake
  • after reconstitution: do not refrigerate, protect from direct sunlight, use within 3 hours
  • for IV use only; administer as IV bolus no faster than 10 mL per minute
  • do not administer in same tubing or container with other drugs

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• plasma Factor IX activity, to determine adequate response
  • prevention or reduction of bleeding episodes indicates efficacy
  • development of neutralizing antibodies; regularly in all patients, but especially with: allergic reactions, bleeding not controlled with recommended dose, or expected Factor IX activity levels not achieved
  • signs and symptoms of acute hypersensitivity reactions; particularly early in treatment

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Side effects may include headache, oral paresthesia, dizziness, or fatigue.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of hypersensitivity (ie, hives, wheezing, difficulty breathing, or tightening of the chest).
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of bleeding after treatment (may indicate development of an inhibitor).
